The ISC can only consider operational matters if the Prime Minister and the ISC agree, and any examination of such matters must be consistent with principles set out in a memorandum of understanding. The ISC must publish an annual report on its activities and lay it before Parliament, and can make other reports to Parliament as necessary. The ISC can make recommendations to the Prime Minister regarding the activities of the intelligence agencies, and the Prime Minister must consider these recommendations.
Additionally, the Justice and Security Act of 2013 allows for the use of "closed material procedures" in certain civil proceedings, meaning that the court can consider evidence that cannot be revealed to the opposing party. This is intended to protect national security interests and ensure that sensitive information is not misused. The court can review and revoke declarations made under Section 6 of the Act, which allows for the use of closed material procedures in certain cases. The court must consider all material presented during the proceedings when determining whether to revoke the declaration.
Finally, the Justice and Security Act of 2013 includes provisions related to the handling of sensitive information in national security cases.
